phrase.item: There once was a miller.
He had nothing besides mills.
He didn't even have a place to live.
He lived by his mills,
baked his own bread and thus fed himself.
Once he placed a piece of bread into the oven, when suddenly, a fox came out of nowhere.
The fox came up to him and began to talk his head off.
The miller's bread, meanwhile, was in the oven.
When the man went off to rake flour away from the mill, the fox ran up, grabbed the bread, and ran off.
The miller chased her for a long time but couldn't catch the fox.
And so the fox ran away, having eaten that man's bread roll.
Another time, the miller once again put a piece of bread into the oven.
That same fox appeared again.
The miller told the fox: "You've already made a fool of me once, fox, get out of here!"
The fox said: "That was another fox, miller, I'm not like that at all, I don't eat bread, I came to chat with you."
The miller said: "If that's the case, then that's good; I'll go pour grain into the mill funnel, and you just sit here a while."
"All right", said the fox.
The miller went to pour grain into the mill funnel.
The fox grabbed the bread and ran off.
The miller chased the fox for a long while but couldn't catch up.
So the fox had carried off and eaten the bread roll.
Just as the miller came back, baked himself [another] bread roll, the fox appeared again.
Seeing the fox, he said: "Go on, get out of here, fox, before I beat you up!"
The fox said: "Why?"
He said:" You stole two pieces of bread from me and ran away, that's why I'll beat you up."
The fox said: "Oh, miller, that was a *different* fox, I'm not that fox, that fox eats bread, but I don't."
He said: "Well, what do you eat then?"
The fox said: "I live on meat."
He said: "All right, wait for me, I'll get back to you in a short while."
The fox said: "All right."
The miller had already placed a piece of bread in the oven.
The fox started talking his head off and meanwhile using its back paws to pull the bread out of the oven discreetly.
Noticing this, the miller grabbed the fox and started laying into it.
The fox pleaded: "Don't beat me, miller, I'll herd your livestock for you!"
The miller took pity on the fox and said: "All right."
The fox asked: "How much livestock have you got, miller?"
He said: "I've got fifty-five heads." The fox said: "Good, I'll herd them for you."
The miller came, fetched his livestock,
counted it, gave it to the fox.
For five years, the fox herded that livestock.
One night, it went and ate up all the livestock, and then ran to the miller, complaining:
"Miller, you didn't affix the gate to the livestock pen tightly enough, all your livestock has wandered off, the wolves have eaten it all up."
The miller came, looks - [sees] the damage that was done to him.
He took half a sheep carcass for himself, and gave [the other] half to the fox, said: "Here, eat this meat, and make me a coat from this skin."
He said: "All right, make me a coat from this skin".
The fox said: "Alright, but I'll need some gluey stuff to dress the sheepskin, send me some flour, I'll smear the skin with it!"
The miller sent the fox a quarter-measure of flour.
The fox made dough out of that flour, smeared the skin with it.
A while later the fox went and ate up all the little skins!
As for the miller, the fox told [him]: "All your skins went rotten, miller.
No coat can be made of them now."
The miller said: "What's to be done now?"
The fox answered: "Now I'll just make you a hat."
He said: "Well, all right." But the fox went and also ate the skins meant for the hat.

And once again the fox called for the miller: "Miller, your skins for the hat all went rotten! But now I'll at least make you mittens, so that when you're mucking around in the mill-water, your hands wouldn't get cold!"
He said: "All right."
But the fox then went and ate up these remaining skins, too.
Once again the fox called the miller: "Miller, the skins for your mittens all went rotten!"
Then the miller grabbed the fox and began to beat it, saying: "You've made a fool time and time again, ate all my livestock, now I'll kill you!"
The fox pleaded: "Don't kill me, miller, I'll arrange a wedding for you, give you such-and-such king's daughter for a bride!"
He said: "You, fox, have tricked me many times."
The fox said: "No, I won't fool you anymore."
The miller let the fox go.
The fox rose and ran off.
She ran to the court of King Shadod.
The courtiers of King Shadod went out of the gates and [found] the fox waiting there. ‎‎
The people entered the house, said: "Shadod, some fox stands by your gates and waits."
He said: "Go on and ask her what sort of a fox she is."
King Shadod's people went out - the fox still stands there, waiting.
They shouted: "Hey, fox! Who are you?
Where did you come from?
Why did you come? Where are you headed?
Go on, answer us!"
They questioned the fox in this manner.
The fox said: "Well, aren't you folks polite, I've been standing [and] waiting by these gates for hours now like a dog, don't tell me you thought I was a person or a dog?
I am also a vizier of such-and-such king, and you kept me like a dog by these gates.
I came to King Shadod's court on business.
Is there anyone here to hear me out?"
They said: "What business do you have?"
The fox answered: "I came to the King's court with a marriage proposal. I want to ask the King's daughter to be my son's bride."
The King became very angry at her: "Would you look at this fox, in charge of such business, I won't give her my dog let alone my child!
Tell her to get lost, or I'll deal with her without mercy!"
Then the King's vizier said: "Don't scold this fox, just set the bride-price for her to pay nice and high, she won't come up with as much livestock as you'll ask of her."
Then he rises, [and] leaves.
Then the King called the fox, said: "Here you are, asking for my daughter, but it's not as if you have as much property as I'll set [as a bride-price]."

The fox said: "King, don't think I'm all helpless, if I were incapable of coming up with the property you set, I wouldn't have even brought this up, I won't anger you, I'll come up with however much property you set, don't you worry!"
The King said: "All right, consider it done that I've given you my daughter, only bring and set before me ten horse-loads of red satin.
If you don't bring the ten horse-loads of red satin I have set, then you better not come close to me!"
The fox said: "All right, I will definitely bring you the things you named."
"So go now, come back here in five days, bring what I told you to!"

The fox rose and leaving said: "Only here is I will tell you, King: keep in mind that the road to you is difficult, the river is very high right now, so when I come, make arrangements for me, pull me out of the river so that the loads I bring get delivered undamaged!"
The King said: "All right, when you come, I'll place one of my men on the river bank." The fox said: "Now that is good."
He ran, gathered from everywhere rags, loaded it all onto ten horses, and showed up.
He rode up to the river bank - none of the king's men were there.

Then the fox cut those packs open with a knife, tosses them in the river, and began to weep bitterly. The King's men heard the fox wailing, ran and informed the King: "O King, the fox came, [and it's] sitting and crying on the river bank."
The King said: "Go and find out what has happened to her that made the fox cry."
They came running, the fox is weeping bitterly.
They asked: "What happened to you, fox, why are you weeping so bitterly?"

The fox said: "Boo-hoo, do you call this treating me fairly, you promised [me] 'sure, we'll be waiting for you on the river bank, but I came up to the river bank - there's no one there, so all my packs with red satin fell off the horses and ended up in the water, what a very unpleasant lesson for me, after all I brought these ten packs of red satin to the King as the bride price for his daughter, and now all those packs of red satin are in the water, so whom should I bill?"
The King thought: "The fox did procure those packs for me as the bride-price after all, but they ended up in the water, now only I am responsible for them."

Then he addressed the fox: "Hey, fox, even though you did not deliver those packs to me, dropped them in the river, but I am to answer for that, so now go and bring your son here, I am giving him my daughter in marriage."
The fox set out.
THe fox brought the miller.
The miller only ever ate bread, he knew no other food, knew no tea, no rice, no meat, no butter, only bread alone.
So the fox brought him over.
They came to the King's court, the King gave him his daughter.
Then the King ordered brought to him rice, tea, all sorts of tasty dishes.
The miller asked then: "What is all this, fox?
What do I do with this?"
The fox said: "You [pitiful] bread-eater, that's human food it is, you've never seen nothing but bread haven't you."
The miller ate everything.
Then they all went to sleep. And in the morning he took the King's daughter [and] rode off home.
They made it back to the place, and lived happily ever after. And that was all.
